Stem: In a newly discovered island ecosystem, scientists have observed small herbivorous mammals, large carnivorous birds, flowering plants, and insects that pollinate the plants. Which of the following BEST predicts the patterns of interactions among these organisms?
Choices: A) The herbivorous mammals will compete with the carnivorous birds for the flowering plants, leading to a decrease in both populations., B) The carnivorous birds will prey on the pollinating insects, causing a decline in flowering plant populations due to reduced pollination., C) The herbivorous mammals will eat the flowering plants, the carnivorous birds will prey on the mammals, and the insects will pollinate the plants, creating a balanced food web., D) The pollinating insects will compete with the herbivorous mammals for the flowering plants, while the carnivorous birds will have no significant interactions with the other organisms. Experimental protocol about plant growth As some students are planting flowers, they notice several earthworms in the soil. One student wonders if earthworms are beneficial to the growth of plants. The student decides to test this by performing an investigation. The student plants identical flowering plants in two containers with potting soil. The treatment for the plants is the same, except that six earthworms are added to one container. Figure 1 shows the plants after 65 days of growth. The plant in the pot with earthworms appears to be healthier. The student describes it as having larger leaves, a thicker and more upright stem, longer roots, and more root hairs than the plant in the container without the earthworms. Based on the observations regarding matter and energy flow in the containers, the student describes the role of the

DCI Justification: Grade-appropriate DCI used for reasoning in context.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement. No patterns, cause/effect, or systems thinking required.
Key Recommendation: Add a real-world phenomenon or puzzling scenario that students need to figure out. Explicitly engage a crosscutting concept (cause/effect, patterns, systems, structure/function).

Stem: Cactus plants have developed sharp spines instead of leaves to minimize water loss in hot environments. These spines also protect the cacti from predators trying to feed on them. Suppose a bird with a long beak is able to feed on cacti with shorter spines. How will the population of cacti change if this behavior continues?
Choices: A) The short-spined cacti population will become larger than the long spined cacti., B) The long-spined cacti population will become larger than the short spined cacti., C) The cacti population will remain constant in future generations, regardless of spine length., D) The cacti population will increase in number to compensate for the losses. Answer Key of Alpha Standardized Science G7.21 1. A 2. A 3. B 4. B 5. C 6. C 7. B, C 8. C 9. D 10. D 11. C 12. D 13. C 14. C 15. A 16. B 17. B 18. C 19. B 20. C 21. D 22. A 23. C 24. C 25. C 26. D 27. C 28. A 29. A 30. D 31. C 32. D 33. D 34. A 35. B
Scenario Justification: Real-world context with meaningful setup. Requires some application.
SEP Justification: No science practice engaged. Recall/identification only.
DCI Justification: DCI present but used at surface level — identification rather than reasoning.
CCC Justification: CCC implicitly present but not engaged for reasoning.
Key Recommendation: Require students to engage in a science practice (analyze data, construct explanation, argue from evidence). Push beyond recall — require students to reason with science ideas, not just identify them.
